page.title: 17THE NEYLAND RAILWAY (1)
page.content:
In{1852}it was decided that there should be a railway to connect{London with{Pembrokeshire}to start a cross channel service to Ireland.
The{South Wales Railway Company}had the choice of either connecting the line to{Neyland}or{Goodwick.
Eventually,{Neyland}was chosen. In{1835 Neyland}was a small fishing village of about 300 people, but great changes were about to be made. {Isambard Kingdom Brunel}was in charge of the project. He built 1st., 2nd. and 3rd. class waiting rooms, a booking hall and a post office in{New {Milford}or{Neyland.}Also there were cattle pens, coal hoists and fishstages. A magnificent hotel was built for Irish ferry passengers to stay in.
